posts.post_content:
Crenel and I are on the same page; this card screams Blue/Red. Terrifying level of land destruction when combined with [Drain Power](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Drain Power) or [Mana Short](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Short).
  
   
Awesome for combo potential
  
   
4/5

posts.post_content:
**Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #20, 10/22/10**   
   
Another day, another red enchantment meant to hose counterspells without explicitly saying so. Price of Glory was released one year after the last card I talked about that did this, Monday’s [Tectonic Instability](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tectonic Instability). I guess R&D was having serious trouble with counterspell decks at that time and found the best way to hose them was with nasty hate like this.
  
   
Despite being almost strictly worse than the paragon of control-hosers, [City of Solitude](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=City of Solitude), this one at least did its job. R&D knew it was going to have an impact, as it was previewed on the now-defunct Sideboard.com by one Brian Kibler nine years ago. I’ve seen it in various sideboards in Standard decks from that era, and there was a time where this was showing up in Vintage sideboards as well. Not only is it good against counters, but anything that might require mana on an opponents’ turn, like activating a [Circle of Pro](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Circle of Pro)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content: I use this in my sideboard for my red/black control deck. If I'm facing a counter heavy blue deck, I bring this out to keep the counters to a minimum. It works really well in this deck, but it's use in almost any other type of deck is limited.

Posted By: riskVSreward (7/27/2009 12:41:40 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't know how efficient it would be to use this against a red deck - they can still burn your creatures during their own turns... But I definitely agree with Gezus; this is like a giant middle finger to anyone playing blue rofl.  
Seems like a nice sideboard option for a land destruction deck - most land destruction spells are sorceries anyway, so you'll rarely end up blowing your own lands to pieces with this. I like the idea of "either you lose your lands, or you cast a counterspell and lose even more lands".
posts.html:
I don't know how efficient it would be to use this against a red deck - they can still burn your creatures during their own turns... But I definitely agree with Gezus; this is like a giant middle finger to anyone playing blue rofl.
Seems like a nice sideboard option for a land destruction deck - most land destruction spells are sorceries anyway, so you'll rarely end up blowing your own lands to pieces with this. I like the idea of "either you lose your lands, or you cast a counterspell and lose even more lands".

Posted By: GrimjawxRULES (7/12/2010 11:37:53 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: This is arguably the best in Blue/Red decks due to the nature of several Blue counter abilities (i.e. "Counter target spell unless its controller pays (X)", [Force Spike](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force Spike)). There's nothing quite as satisfying to me as saying, "Either I snuff one of your most important spells or you lose out on extra land." Of course it defeats the purpose of traditional Blue/Red which allows you to cast during an opponent's turn, but when played right it's quite humorous.
posts.html:
This is arguably the best in Blue/Red decks due to the nature of several Blue counter abilities (i.e. "Counter target spell unless its controller pays (X)", Force Spike). There's nothing quite as satisfying to me as saying, "Either I snuff one of your most important spells or you lose out on extra land." Of course it defeats the purpose of traditional Blue/Red which allows you to cast during an opponent's turn, but when played right it's quite humorous.

Posted By: Max_Glycine (6/10/2011 6:19:20 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I had this card played against me once. I was playing Psychatog in Standard(and had that little Grinning Buscemi in play) when my opponent decided to cast this card. My kneejerk reaction was to counter it at all costs. Luckily, I decided to actually look at the game state and do some math. I said 'Sure' and let it resolve. When my opponent said go, I got rid of anything in the way and tapped a few other lands to get them in the yard. Untap, swing with Psychatog for exactsies by removing all those lands that were now in my graveyard.   
  
My opponent was less than happy with this chain of events.
posts.html:

Untap, swing with Psychatog for exactsies by removing all those lands that were now in my graveyard.

My opponent was less than happy with this chain of events.

Posted By: DHThomas (6/3/2011 9:08:18 AM)

posts.post_content:
Ha! I remember this so well! I used it in a multiplayer combo deck. With [Sacred Ground](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sacred Ground ) in play, you [Donate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Donate ) [Price of Glory](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Price of Glory ) to an opponent to make infinite mana on other players' turns (and [Donate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Donate ) is largely protected from counters by [Price of Glory](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Price of Glory)'s ability). What fun!  
Admittedly [Donate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Donate ) soon found other horrors to give away, but I enjoyed giving away many different terrible things :)
posts.html:

Admittedly Donate soon found other horrors to give away, but I enjoyed giving away many different terrible things :)

Posted By: 4sythe (6/3/2011 7:48:43 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: [Mana Short](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Short) combined with this won't destroy all your opponents lands unless he or she taps out all of their land in response to your spell. Since Mana Short taps the lands itself and NOT the opponent. This enchantment says that the player has to tap the land for mana themselves. [Drain Power](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Drain Power) on the other hand would destroy all their lands.
posts.html:
Mana Short combined with this won't destroy all your opponents lands unless he or she taps out all of their land in response to your spell. Since Mana Short taps the lands itself and NOT the opponent. This enchantment says that the player has to tap the land for mana themselves. Drain Power on the other hand would destroy all their lands.
